senses.de: to be or make up something
senses.ex: Women constitute half of the population in the world.

Tips.title: Quantifiable Parts
Tips.description: Used for things that can be measured or counted to show composition.
Tips.example: Five regions constitute the entire federation.

Tips.title: Portion Composition
Tips.description: Refers to parts that combine to form a whole, often used in scientific or analytical contexts.
Tips.example: Various gases constitute our planet's atmosphere.

senses.ex: They constitute a new government after the elections.

Tips.title: Official Formation
Tips.description: Emphasizes the formal creation of an entity, system, or organization.
Tips.example: The peace treaty will constitute a new alliance.

Tips.title: Legal Context
Tips.description: Points to a legal or formal process rather than an informal one.
Tips.example: By signing this document, you constitute a binding agreement.

senses.ex: In some cultures, certain animals constitute luck or prosperity.

Tips.title: Cultural Symbolism
Tips.description: Links to ideas or objects that have specific meaning within a cultural context.
Tips.example: Olive branches constitute peace in many cultures.

Tips.title: Metaphor Indication
Tips.description: Shows that 'constitute' can be used when one thing is an indication or symbol of another.
Tips.example: These actions constitute a clear warning to opponents.

Tips.title: Abstract Relationships
Tips.description: Helps understand connections where 'constitute' implies abstract or non-tangible relationships.
Tips.example: Trust and respect constitute the foundation of a healthy relationship.

Be.wordDefinition:
Be means to exist or to equal something. It is applicable when you want to describe the state of being or when you want to identify something.

Example: I am happy. This means I exist in a state of happiness.

Constitute means to form or make up something. It is applicable when you want to describe the parts that make up a whole.

Example: The team is constituted of five players. This means the team is made up of five players.

Be describes a state of being while constitute describes the parts that make up a whole.

Compose.wordDefinition:
Compose means to create or form something by combining different parts, while constitute means to make up or be a part of something.

For example, a song is composed of different parts like lyrics, melody, and harmony. In this case, you would use compose to describe the process of putting those elements together to make a complete song.

You would use compose to describe the process of bringing together different parts to create something new, while constitute describes how something is made up of its individual parts.

Comprise.wordDefinition:
Both words, comprise and constitute, refer to the parts that make up a whole.

Comprise means to be composed of or to include all the parts, elements or components that make up the whole.

Example: The committee comprises five members.

Therefore, when talking about a whole, comprise is used whereas when talking about the parts, constitute is used.

Create.wordDefinition:
Create means to make or bring something into existence. For example, an artist can create a painting by putting colors on a canvas.

Constitute is applicable when you want to talk about the components that make up something, while create is applicable when you want to talk about producing or making something new.

Establish.wordDefinition:
Establish means to set up, create, or start something new or permanent. For example, "The government established a new law to protect the environment.".

To simplify, the difference between the two words is that constitute refers to the composition or makeup of something while establish refers to the act of creating something new.

Form.wordDefinition:
The words constitute and form both refer to something being made up of smaller parts, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Form is a more general word that can refer to any parts that come together to make something whole.

You might say that a group of molecules form a chemical compound, or that individual bricks form a wall.

Constitute is used when you need to specifically identify the essential parts of something, while form can be used more broadly to describe any parts that come together to create a whole.

Make up.wordDefinition:
The words constitute and make up have similar meanings but are used in different contexts.

Constitute means to form or make up the essential parts of something. For example, the 50 states constitute the United States of America.

Make up means to form or compose something. For example, the students make up the majority of the school population. This indicates that the students compose or form the school's population.

Make up is used when referring to parts that are not necessarily essential but still play a part in the whole.

The key difference is that constitute is used when referring to essential parts, while make up is used when referring to all parts, whether essential or not.

Organize.wordDefinition:
Constitute means to make up or form something, while the word organize means to put something in order or arrange it.

On the other hand, organizing can refer to arranging items in a room, scheduling events for a calendar, or putting together a system for filing papers.

In this case, organize refers to process of putting things in order or planning something out.

Constitute describes what makes up something, while organize describes the process or act of putting something together in a particular way.

quotes.Text: The glory of justice and the majesty of law are created not just by the Constitution - nor by the courts - nor by the officers of the law - nor by the lawyers - but by the men and women who constitute our society - who are the protectors of the law as they are themselves protected by the law.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Robert Kennedy

quotes.Text: The poorest parts of the world are by and large the places in which one can best view the worst of medicine and not because doctors in these countries have different ideas about what constitutes modern medicine. It's the system and its limitations that are to blame.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Paul Farmer

quotes.Text: Books constitute capital. A library book lasts as long as a house, for hundreds of years. It is not, then, an article of mere consumption but fairly of capital, and often in the case of professional men, setting out in life, it is their only capital.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Thomas Jefferson

quotes.Text: One might think that the money value of an invention constitutes its reward to the man who loves his work. But... I continue to find my greatest pleasure, and so my reward, in the work that precedes what the world calls success.
quotes.Title: American Inventor
quotes.Name: Thomas A. Edison

quotes.Text: It is not the truth that a man possesses, or believes that he possesses, but the earnest effort which he puts forward to reach the truth, which constitutes the worth of a man.
quotes.Title: German Critic
quotes.Name: Gotthold Ephraim Lessing

quotes.Text: To practice five things under all circumstances constitutes perfect virtue; these five are gravity, generosity of soul, sincerity, earnestness, and kindness.
quotes.Title: Chinese Philosopher
quotes.Name: Confucius

quotes.Text: There is no such thing as inner peace. There is only nervousness or death. Any attempt to prove otherwise constitutes unacceptable behavior.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Fran Lebowitz

quotes.Text: Nothing has been purchased more dearly than the little bit of reason and sense of freedom which now constitutes our pride.
quotes.Title: German Philosopher
quotes.Name: Friedrich Nietzsche

quotes.Text: The applause is a celebration not only of the actors but also of the audience. It constitutes a shared moment of delight.
quotes.Title: Hungarian Scientist
quotes.Name: John Polanyi

quotes.Text: The years from about eight to twelve constitute a unique period of human life.
quotes.Title: American Psychologist
quotes.Name: G. Stanley Hall
